text: You're calling the function as a method.
Add "self" as the first argument and it'll work.
You have not posted all of your code.
The code you didn't post looks like this:

code:
class SomeClass:

    def gcd(a,b):
        if a == 0:
                return b
        while b != 0:
                if a > b:
                        a = a - b
                else:
                        b = b - a
        return a 

G = SomeClass()
G.gcd(1,2)

text: In python, when you define a class member function, the class instance is automatically passed to the function.
Change your code to look like this:

code:
class SomeClass:

    def gcd(a,b):
        if a == 0:
                return b
        while b != 0:
                if a > b:
                        a = a - b
                else:
                        b = b - a
        return a 

G = SomeClass()
G.gcd(1,2)

text: or better yet

code:
def gcd( a,b):
    if a == 0:
            return b
    while b != 0:
            if a > b:
                    a = a - b
            else:
                    b = b - a
    return a 

gcd(1,2)

text: and all will be well.
You could use the staticmethod decorator like this:
if gcd is a method inside the class then you should define it as follows:
def gcd(self, a, b): etc.
I suspect (since the error is in code you haven't provided) that gcd is actually a method and you are calling it as obj.gcd(a,b).
This is translated as gcd(self, a, b) = 3 arguments.
you need to define the function with the self argument.

There's already an accepted answer that solves the problem, but I'd like to point out, that (IMHO) a more idiomatic solution in Python would be to move the gcd method outside the class to a plain function in the module.
I mean, it's a general purpose function.
There's no reason in Python to encapsulate it in a class.
I just threw that code into Python (in interpreter mode) and it seems to work just fine.
Are you sure gcd isn't being redefined anywhere?
Python will allow you to redefine functions without warning, if I remember correctly.
The code as you provide it, works fine in an interpreter.
If you're calling gcd() as a method, you need to add "self" as first argument.
